"If we don't reprioritize, restructure and reinvent, the federal tax burden will have to more than double over the next 20 years. We will pass a tipping point in about 20 years where this just spins out of control." The numbers beyond the spin-out are not pretty. The U.S. Treasury's 2007 Guide to Understanding the Annual Financial Report of the United States shows, in Chart A, "Current Trends Are Not Sustainable," reports that Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid account for half the federal budget by 2030; but not for long. Fifteen years later, interest will exceed the cost of Social Security; and 30 years later, interest will consume nothing less than half of America's gross domestic product. Thus, the question for today's financial executives is whether their companies can sustain the economic stress brought on by that unsustainable federal deficit. Walker's warnings are replete with signs of danger for American businesses. At some point, if nothing changes the current course, foreign investors who currently pay interest on the federal debt may realize that the U.S. may not be able to pay back what it owes. Only higher interest rates would balance that perceived risk enough to continue to attract investment. Domestic interest rates must react accordingly. As the value of the dollar plummets, the cost of imported goods soars, and the nation's current account tilts precipitously. As more of the federal budget goes to finance the swelling debt, less will go to maintenance and improvement of the national infrastructure. As communication, transportation and energy production become less efficient, the economy will perform less well than projected. As tax revenues decline, the problem starts to feed itself. content: I read two very long articles yesterday on the details and consequences of the budget deficit. It is VERY ALARMING… You can check them out here: …http: //www.allbusiness.com/government/government-bodies-offices/11730990-1.html… … http: //blogs.ft.com/maverecon/2009/01/can-the-us-economy-afford-a-keynesian-stimulus/ …and if you copy the above addresses – there is a “space” between the semi colon and forward slashes… According this economist – the 9-trillion dollar debt is seriously misleading – it is technically and literally – $ 56,000,000,000,000.00 - yep, 56-Trillion Dollars… These articles are well worth the read… Essentially – the first article explains why the debt is actually 56-Trillion … He shows using GOA real-deal numbers that even THEY know it’s true… Here’s the thing though… According to these guys – Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security will consume 50% of the Fed budget by 2030… So, most folks know this and there is time to deal with it… BUT Here’s a snip from the article… Elements of the Problem "There's a real risk that if we don't get our financial house in order, we'll see interest rates go up, which will have a ripple effect on other aspects of the economy," Walker warns. "If we don't reprioritize, restructure and reinvent, the federal tax burden will have to more than double over the next 20 years. We will pass a tipping point in about 20 years where this just spins out of control." The numbers beyond the spin-out are not pretty. The U.S. Treasury's 2007 Guide to Understanding the Annual Financial Report of the United States shows, in Chart A, "Current Trends Are Not Sustainable," reports that Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid account for half the federal budget by 2030; but not for long. Fifteen years later, interest will exceed the cost of Social Security; and 30 years later, interest will consume nothing less than half of America's gross domestic product. Thus, the question for today's financial executives is whether their companies can sustain the economic stress brought on by that unsustainable federal deficit. Walker's warnings are replete with signs of danger for American businesses. At some point, if nothing changes the current course, foreign investors who currently pay interest on the federal debt may realize that the U.S. may not be able to pay back what it owes. Only higher interest rates would balance that perceived risk enough to continue to attract investment. Domestic interest rates must react accordingly. As the value of the dollar plummets, the cost of imported goods soars, and the nation's current account tilts precipitously. As more of the federal budget goes to finance the swelling debt, less will go to maintenance and improvement of the national infrastructure. As communication, transportation and energy production become less efficient, the economy will perform less well than projected. As tax revenues decline, the problem starts to feed itself. And down we go. In about 20 years, Walker explains, the national debt as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) will reach third-world status. Michael E. Lewitt, president of Capital Management LLC, says the current Wall Street crisis and impending government fiscal crisis are linked, with the government's increasing thirst for borrowed money slamming up against the financial industry's need for capital. ----------end --- snip ---------- Obama was going to raise taxes to same height as the Carter years…. That’s when the unemployment checks start running out for these folks and from there out – it only gets worse and it does so picking up momentum. All of these people are getting laid off – WERE paying taxes. NOW they are getting money from the fed-drawer… That means NEXT YEAR the Fed’s money will be steadily decreasing akin to someone puncturing a three inch hole in the side of an above ground pool. It starts with spurting with pressure then begins to rip until – you get the picture… This debt is SO HUGE by the time our grand kids are hoping to buy SOMETHING – the country won’t even be able to make the payments. How long will China hold out before they start taking action or instigating Chavez along with the Soviets by then comfy cozy in Cuba…? Maybe that’s a little too far-fetched – most of us won’t be here to find out. Hope everyone gets to take their kids and grandkids to Disneyland before too long… at least there will be some memories… The 110th Congress that destroyed the American and ended the great experiment. They traded their freedom for their socialist fantasies… what a disgrace they are – and that is ALL of them BOTH sides of the isles – REPUBLICAN & DEMOCRAT….

"If we don't reprioritize, restructure and reinvent, the federal tax burden will have to more than double over the next 20 years. We will pass a tipping point in about 20 years where this just spins out of control." The numbers beyond the spin-out are not pretty. The U.S. Treasury's 2007 Guide to Understanding the Annual Financial Report of the United States shows, in Chart A, "Current Trends Are Not Sustainable," reports that Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid account for half the federal budget by 2030; but not for long. Fifteen years later, interest will exceed the cost of Social Security; and 30 years later, interest will consume nothing less than half of America's gross domestic product. Thus, the question for today's financial executives is whether their companies can sustain the economic stress brought on by that unsustainable federal deficit. Walker's warnings are replete with signs of danger for American businesses. At some point, if nothing changes the current course, foreign investors who currently pay interest on the federal debt may realize that the U.S. may not be able to pay back what it owes. Only higher interest rates would balance that perceived risk enough to continue to attract investment. Domestic interest rates must react accordingly. As the value of the dollar plummets, the cost of imported goods soars, and the nation's current account tilts precipitously. As more of the federal budget goes to finance the swelling debt, less will go to maintenance and improvement of the national infrastructure. As communication, transportation and energy production become less efficient, the economy will perform less well than projected. As tax revenues decline, the problem starts to feed itself. And down we go. In about 20 years, Walker explains, the national debt as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) will reach third-world status. Michael E. Lewitt, president of Capital Management LLC, says the current Wall Street crisis and impending government fiscal crisis are linked, with the government's increasing thirst for borrowed money slamming up against the financial industry's need for capital. ----------end --- snip ---------- Obama was going to raise taxes to same height as the Carter years….
